Electric field E in the gap between two cylinders is E = U/L.
Force F acting on the electron is F = eE.
Acceleration a of the electron is a = eU/mL.
Velocity v_1 of the electron as it enters cylinder 1 is v_1 = sqrt(2eU/m).
Lengths of the cylinders must be designed such that the electron completes its acceleration within the time period T of the AC power supply.
Distance s traveled by the electron in time t is s = 1/2 * a * (T/2)^2.
Distance s simplifies to s = eUT^2/8mL.
Length L_n of the nth metal cylinder is L_n = eUT^2/8mL.
Electron starts from rest and is accelerated by the electric field between the plate and cylinder 1, entering cylinder 1 along the central axis.
As the electron enters cylinder 1, it continues to be accelerated by the electric field until it exits cylinder 1.
Electron enters the gap between cylinder 1 and cylinder 2, where it is not accelerated.
As the electron enters cylinder 2, it continues to be accelerated by the electric field until it exits cylinder 2.
Motion of the electron can be analyzed using the equations of motion, taking into account the acceleration and distance traveled in each segment of the path.
